name: tall oil refinery operation | rosin size, for paper production | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18061/documentation

This dataset represents the distillation of 1 kg of crude tall oil in a fractionation column to more valuable intermediate pine chemicals: (unsaponifiables/) tall oil heads, pitch, tall oil rosin (TOR), tall oil fatty acids (TOFA) and distilled tall oil (DTO). These products were matched with ecoinvent product names as follows:;;•	TALL OIL ROSIN: “rosin size, for paper production”;Main use of TOR is as paper sizing.;;•	TALL OIL FATTY ACIDS: “fatty acids”;Main uses for TOFA is as surfactants, in paints, coatings and olified chemicals.;;•	PITCH: “pitch”;Pitch is often used internally as a process fuel.;;•	DISTILLED TALL OIL: “fatty acids”;	Main uses in the end markets of surfactants, paints and rubber;;•	HEADS: “fatty acids”, ;Often (partially) used as internal process fuel;;;TOR was defined as the driver fot this refinery operation process and was hence set to be the reference product,  following the "EU CTO - Added Value Study" study (Fraunhofer,2016) , which suggest that the tall oil resin production in the European Union has a signifcantly higher total added value than tall oil fatty acid production. ;Data represent 100% of the US stand-alone tall oil distillation capacity in 2011, which includes 5 sites and >90% of the European capacity, which includes 4 sites (Cashman et al., 2015). A weighted average of US and European data was calculated, applying the shares of these regions in global tall oil rosin (TOR) production in 2014, of 49% and 32%, respectively (Baumassy & Forchem, 2014). Scaling this up to 100% the applied weighing factors are 0.605 and 0.395 respectively. Data hence represent around 80% of global TOR production.;Reference(s):;;Cashman, S.A., Moran, K.M., Gaglione, A.G., 2015, Greenhouse Gas and Energy Life Cycle Assessment of Pine Chemicals Derived from Crude Tall Oil and Their Substitutes, Wiley Online Library, https://doi.org/10.1111/jiec.12370;;Baumassy, M., Forchem, O., 2014, The Talloil Industry : 100 years of Innovation, accessed online at https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.pinechemicals.org/resource/collection/C9836B4C-DDF1-4725-82D5-AAA0E89C2311/Michel_Baumassy_-_The_Tall_Oil_Industry_-_100_Years_of_Innovation.pdf, 28.6.2018;;Fraunhofer Institute for Environmental, Safety and Energy Technology UMSICHT, 2016, ANALYSIS OF THE EUROPEAN CRUDE TALL OIL INDUSTRY - ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT, SOCIO-ECONOMIC VALUE & DOWNSTREAM POTENTIAL, online at https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.pinechemicals.org/resource/resmgr/Studies/EU_CTO_Added_Value_Study_Fin.pdf, July 2017

From reception of crude tall oil at the refinery gate through refining of crude tall oil.  

System boundary is set by the boundaries of the refinery.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/104:Manufacture of vegetable and animal oils and fats/1040:Manufacture of vegetable and animal oils and fats

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Energy data for 2008; process inputs and other data from literature sources.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent 100% of the US stand-alone tall oil distillation capacity in 2011, which includes 5 sites and >90% of the European capacity, which includes 4 sites (Cashman et al., 2015). A weighted average of US and European data was calculated, applying the shares of these regions in global tall oil rosin (TOR) production in 2014, of 49% and 32%, respectively (Baumassy & Forchem, 2014). Scaling this up to 100% the applied weighing factors are 0.605 and 0.395 respectively.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Distillation of crude tall oil in a fractionation column.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
A weighted average of US and European data was calculated, applying the shares of these regions in global tall oil rosin (TOR) production in 2014, of 49% and 32%, respectively (Baumassy & Forchem, 2014). Scaling this up to 100% the applied weighing factors are 0.605 and 0.395 respectively. 
Reference(s): Baumassy, M., Forchem, O., 2014, The Talloil Industry : 100 years of Innovation, accessed online at <https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.pinechemicals.org/resource/collection/C9836B4C-DDF1-4725-82D5-AAA0E89C2311/Michel_Baumassy_-_The_Tall_Oil_Industry_-_100_Years_of_Innovation.pdf>, 28.6.2018
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data taken from literature. Main source: Cashman, S.A., Moran, K.M., Gaglione, A.G., 2015, Greenhouse Gas and Energy Life Cycle Assessment of Pine Chemicals Derived from Crude Tall Oil and Their Substitutes, Wiley Online Library, <https://doi.org/10.1111/jiec.12370>

exchanges.description:
tall oil rosin (TOR) is assumed to be the driver of this refinery operation and hence the reference product, following the 
 "EU CTO - Added Value Study" study, which suggest that the tall oil resin production in the European Union has a signifcantly higher total added value than tall oil fatty acid production. Reference(s): 
Fraunhofer Institute for Environmental, Safety and Energy Technology UMSICHT, 2016, ANALYSIS OF THE EUROPEAN CRUDE TALL OIL INDUSTRY - ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT, SOCIO-ECONOMIC VALUE & DOWNSTREAM POTENTIAL, online at https://c.ymcdn.com/sites/www.pinechemicals.org/resource/resmgr/Studies/EU_CTO_Added_Value_Study_Fin.pdf, July 2017

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the on-site combustion of fuels was calculated based on emission profiles of the following ecoinvent furnace/boiler processes. The geography of the combustion process was chosen depending on whether the fuel is used in the US, the European or both tall oil distillation processes: light fuel oil: heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; heavy fuel oil: heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; bituminous coal: heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, GLO; natural gas: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, GLO; combustion of pitch, head and distilled tall oil was approximated with emissions from: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 300kW, GLO

exchanges.description: Reported as an input steam purchased from pulp and paper mills. In Europe the purchased amount is 0.584MJ. Subtracted thereof is an amount of 0.0619kg steam output which is sold to the paper industry (1MJ=0.3636kg). This is only the case in Europe, not in the US (purchased heat of 433MJ). A weighted average for US and Europe was calculated. As the source of the heat is specified to be pulp (and paper) mills, direct activity links were therefore set to heat from sulfate pulp producing activities by share of their heat production volumes.

exchanges.description: Reported as an input steam purchased from pulp and paper mills. In Europe the purchased amount is 0.584MJ. Subtracted thereof is an amount of 0.0619kg steam output which is sold to the paper industry (1MJ=0.3636kg). This is only the case in Europe, not in the US (purchased heat of 433MJ). A weighted average for US and Europe was calculated. As the source of the heat is specified to be pulp (and paper) mills, direct activity links were therefore set to heat from sulfate pulp producing activities by share of their heat production volumes.

exchanges.description: Reported as an input steam purchased from pulp and paper mills. In Europe the purchased amount is 0.584MJ. Subtracted thereof is an amount of 0.0619kg steam output which is sold to the paper industry (1MJ=0.3636kg). This is only the case in Europe, not in the US (purchased heat of 433MJ). A weighted average for US and Europe was calculated. As the source of the heat is specified to be pulp (and paper) mills, direct activity links were therefore set to heat from sulfate pulp producing activities by share of their heat production volumes.
